sentence: A 16-year-old healthy female presents to her pediatrician concerned that she has not had a menstrual period. She has no past medical history and takes no medications. She plays volleyball and gets good grades in school. Her BMI is 22 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals normal female external genitalia and pubic hair along the mons pubis and superomedial thighs. Her breasts appear normal. Transabdominal ultrasound reveals an absent uterus. Serum testosterone levels is within the normal range for females. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
rationale:
1. The patient's presentation of primary amenorrhea, normal external genitalia, absent uterus, and normal serum testosterone levels is consistent with Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome, which is caused by failure of paramesonephric duct development.

2. Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) typically presents with irregular menstrual periods, signs of androgen excess, and polycystic ovaries on ultrasound, none of which are present in this patient.

3. Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) would present with a 46,XY karyotype, normal female external genitalia, and absent uterus, but the patient's normal serum testosterone levels make this diagnosis less likely.

4. Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45,X karyotype, short stature, and ovarian dysgenesis, which are not present in this patient.

5. Hypothalamic amenorrhea is typically seen in athletes or individuals with low body weight, which is not the case for this patient.

In conclusion, the most likely cause of this patient's condition is failure of paramesonephric duct development, leading to MRKH syndrome.

sentence: A 61-year-old nulliparous woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Her last Pap smear 3 years ago showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. HPV testing was negative at that time. On questioning, she has had fatigue and an increase in abdominal girth despite a 5-kg (11.0-lb) weight loss over the past 6 months. She has gastroesophageal reflux disease and Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Menarche was at the age of 10 years and her last menstrual period was 2 years ago. Current medications include omeprazole and levothyroxine. Abdominal examination shows shifting dullness. There is tenderness to palpation of the right lower quadrant but no guarding or rebound. Bimanual palpation shows a small uterus and a right adnexal mass. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
rationale:
1. The patient's symptoms, including fatigue, abdominal distension, weight loss, and a right adnexal mass, are concerning for ovarian cancer.
2. The presence of a right adnexal mass and shifting dullness on abdominal examination are suggestive of ascites, which is a common finding in advanced ovarian cancer.
3. Therefore, further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show an elevated serum CA-125 level, which is a tumor marker often elevated in ovarian cancer.
4. The other distractors, including elevated serum estradiol, progesterone, LH, and FSH levels, are not typically associated with the presentation described and are less likely to be found in the context of this patient's symptoms.

sentence: An unresponsive 92-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance and is quickly followed by his grand-daughter. Approx. 1 month ago, he had a radical prostatectomy, pelvic radiation, and several rounds of chemotherapy for aggressive prostate cancer in Nicaragua and was discharged from the hospital with a suprapelvic catheter and a plan for more chemotherapy. He was coming to the United States to spend time with some extended family. According to the grand-daughter his mental status was altered upon arrival and his health began to decline. She is not aware of his past medical status or medications. At the hospital, his blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg, the pulse id 110/min, the respiratory rate is 21/min, and the temperature is 35.6°C (96.1°F). On physical exam, the patient appears cachectic, drowsy, and only responds to questions by nodding his head. His heart rate is tachycardic with a regular rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The cystotomy incision for his suprapelvic catheter is red and swollen. The patient admitted to the hospital and stabilized and started on broad-spectrum antibiotics. The catheter tube produces no urine over 24 hours and only thick green-white puss can be expressed. The treatment team concludes this patient has urinary tract obstruction. What is the best method to evaluate urinary tract obstruction in this patient?
rationale:
Given the patient's unstable condition and the need for a quick evaluation, ultrasound is the best method to evaluate urinary tract obstruction in this patient. It is non-invasive and can provide information about the presence of obstruction and the condition of the kidneys and bladder.

A CT scan and MRI may provide more detailed information, but they are not as readily available and may take longer to perform.

Cystoscopy is an invasive procedure and may not be suitable for a patient in this condition.

An intravenous pyelogram involves the use of contrast dye and may not be appropriate for a patient with renal insufficiency or unstable hemodynamics.

sentence: A 51-year-old man presents to his primary care provider for intermittent shaking of his hands. He reports that for the last several years he has noticed this "shaking" when he brushes his teeth and prepares a cup of coffee in the morning. The shaking then gradually improves over the course of the day. His past medical history is otherwise notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His only home medication is pravastatin. The patient smokes half a pack per day of cigarettes and drinks 2-3 beers throughout the day. His family history is significant for Parkinson disease in his father. On physical exam, his blood pressure is 159/84, pulse is 74/min, and respirations are 12/min. He has a high frequency bilateral hand tremor elicited on finger-to-nose testing. His neurological exam is otherwise unremarkable. This patient should be started on which of the following medications?
rationale:
1. The patient's symptoms of intermittent shaking of his hands, especially in the morning, are consistent with essential tremor.
2. Essential tremor is often treated with beta blockers such as propranolol, which can help reduce the tremor.
3. Levodopa, amantadine, and selegiline are medications used to treat Parkinson's disease, not essential tremor.
4. Benztropine is an anticholinergic medication used to treat drug-induced Parkinsonism, not essential tremor.
5. Therefore, the most appropriate medication for this patient would be propranolol to help with his hand tremors.

sentence: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after a motor vehicle accident. He is unconscious upon arrival and is found to have severe internal bleeding due to trauma. He is taken for emergency surgery and severely damaged tissues are removed. After surgery, the boy is taken into the PICU for recovery. Over the subsequent week, serial labs are drawn showing target cells, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis. He is started on a prophylactic regimen that is continued upon discharge. Which of the following is consistent with the mechanism of action of the drug that was most likely prescribed in this case?
rationale:
1. The patient had severe internal bleeding due to trauma and underwent surgery to remove severely damaged tissues. This suggests that the patient may be at risk for infection due to the open wounds and tissue damage.

2. The presence of target cells, thrombocytosis, and leukocytosis in the serial labs suggests that the patient may be at risk for infection and inflammation, which is common after trauma and surgery.

3. The drug most likely prescribed in this case is a cell wall cross-linking inhibitor, such as a beta-lactam antibiotic (e.g., penicillin or cephalosporin), which works by inhibiting the synthesis of the bacterial cell wall, leading to cell lysis and death.

4. Fibrinolytic agents, platelet aggregation inhibitors, anticoagulants, and thrombolytic agents are not indicated in this case, as the patient's symptoms and history do not suggest a need for these types of medications.

sentence: A 25-year-old man presents to his primary care provider complaining of several weeks of intense itching, particularly localized around his anus. The scotch tape test is positive. The patient has a previous documented allergy to albendazole. Which of the following is an alternative medication that can be used?
rationale:
1. The patient's symptoms and positive scotch tape test are consistent with a diagnosis of pinworm infection.
2. Given the patient's allergy to albendazole, an alternative medication that can be used to treat pinworm infection is pyrantel pamoate.
3. Mebendazole is in the same class as albendazole and may cause a similar allergic reaction in the patient.

5. Praziquantel is used to treat different types of parasitic infections, such as schistosomiasis and tapeworm infections, but not pinworm infection.

7. Therefore, the most appropriate alternative medication for the patient is pyrantel pamoate.

sentence: A 21-year-old female presents to the office after a health screening in which she was found to have high blood pressure. At the office, the blood pressure is 168/114 mm Hg. You have seen the patient in the past for amenorrhea and infertility issues, but she denies taking any medication at this time. On examination, the patient is short and normal weight but has a webbed neck. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the elevated blood pressure?
rationale:
1. The patient's history of amenorrhea and infertility, along with the physical exam finding of a webbed neck, are suggestive of Turner syndrome.
2. Turner syndrome is associated with various cardiovascular abnormalities, including coarctation of the aorta and renal abnormalities such as horseshoe kidney or central fusion of the inferior poles of the kidneys.
3. The combination of hypertension and a webbed neck makes central fusion of the inferior poles of the kidneys the most likely cause of the elevated blood pressure in this patient.
4. Essential hypertension is less likely given the patient's young age and the presence of other suggestive findings for Turner syndrome.
5. Pheochromocytoma and renal artery stenosis are less likely given the patient's clinical presentation and history.
6. Therefore, the most likely cause of the elevated blood pressure in this patient is central fusion of the inferior poles of the kidneys, which is associated with Turner syndrome.

sentence: A 25-year-old African American man presents to his primary care provider for routine blood work. He is a well-known case of sickle cell disease treated with hydroxyurea and tramadol as needed for pain. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. The patient asks if his disease can adversely affect his kidneys because his friend was recently diagnosed with end-stage renal failure. rationale:
1. Sickle cell disease can lead to impaired urine concentration ability due to the vaso-occlusive episodes that can occur in the renal medulla, leading to decreased blood flow and impaired concentration of urine.
2. Glomerulonephritis is not a common renal complication of sickle cell disease.
3. Nephrotic syndrome is also not a common renal complication of sickle cell disease.
4. Renal artery stenosis and renal cell carcinoma are not typically associated with sickle cell disease.
Therefore, the most likely renal complication of sickle cell disease is impaired urine concentration ability.

sentence: A gunshot victim is brought to the Emergency Department and appears to be in shock. You note a penetrating wound at the level of L3. Assuming the bullet remained at this level, which vascular structure might have been injured?

A clinical trial is conducted to test the efficacy of a new drug, A, to treat tinea versicolor. A total of 500 participants are recruited for the study and are randomized into 2 groups in equal numbers. Group 1, the study treatment group, is given drug A, while group 2, the control group, is given the current standard antifungal therapy. After the completion of therapy, 190 participants from the study treatment group and 165 participants from the control group are cured. Which calculation below represents the number needed to treat for the new drug?
rationale:
The number needed to treat (NNT) is calculated by taking the reciprocal of the absolute risk reduction. The absolute risk reduction is calculated by subtracting the event rate in the treated group from the event rate in the control group.

In this case, the event rate in the treated group is 190/250 = 0.76 and the event rate in the control group is 165/250 = 0.66. 

So, the absolute risk reduction is 0.76 - 0.66 = 0.1.

Therefore, the NNT is 1/0.1 = 10.

So, the correct calculation for the NNT for the new drug is 250/25.

sentence: A 38-year-old woman is being evaluated by her primary care physician for chronic, widespread pain that started around 5 months ago. This pain has been accompanied by sleeping issues. rationale:

3. The patient's history of generalized anxiety disorder and previous use of paroxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), suggests that paroxetine may be an effective treatment option for her fibromyalgia symptoms.

5. Therefore, the best treatment option for the most likely diagnosis of fibromyalgia in this patient is paroxetine.

sentence: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle accident. On presentation, he is found to have scalp and trunk lacerations that are still actively bleeding. He has no past medical history and does not take any medications. On presentation, his temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 110/74 mmHg, pulse is 82/min, and respirations are 17/min. rationale:
1. The patient's presentation with actively bleeding lacerations and anxiety suggests a state of hypovolemic shock.

sentence:

sentence: Hypoxia-inducible factor 1-alpha (HIF-1a) is a transcription factor with increased activity under conditions of cellular hypoxia. In normoxia, von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) protein hydroxylates prolyl residues on oxygen-dependent degradation domains of HIF-1a, targeting it for proteasomal degradation. Hydroxylation by VHL is inhibited under hypoxic conditions, allowing HIF-1a to escape degradation, dimerize with HIF-1ß, and translocate to the nucleus. This results in the upregulation of hypoxic response elements, leading to angiogenesis. Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) can mimic the hypoxic state to promote angiogenesis by inhibiting HIF-1a hydroxylation, even in the absence of hypoxia. A researcher wants to perform an experiment to detect HIF-1a in RCC under normoxic conditions with blotting techniques. Which of the following statements are most likely to be true regarding her experiment?
generated_distractors: A Western blot will show decreased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.
A Northern blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.
A Southern blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.
A Western blot will not be able to detect HIF-1α under normoxic conditions.
rationale:
1. In RCC, HIF-1a is not degraded under normoxic conditions, leading to increased levels of HIF-1a compared to a normoxic control.
2. A Western blot is used to detect specific proteins in a sample, so it is the most appropriate technique for detecting HIF-1a levels in RCC under normoxic conditions.
3. A Northern blot is used to detect specific RNA molecules, not proteins like HIF-1a.
4. A Southern blot is used to detect specific DNA sequences, not proteins like HIF-1a.
5. Therefore, the most likely outcome of the researcher's experiment is that a Western blot will show increased HIF-1α compared to a normoxic control.

sentence: A 25-year-old primigravida is admitted to the hospital at 36 weeks gestation after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She is conscious, but lethargic and complains of a headache that started 2 hours prior to the seizure. She denies alcohol intake or drug use. She has no history of convulsive disorders and the antepartum course has been unremarkable. She was compliant with the recommended prenatal care and her last prenatal visit was 2 weeks ago. She has gained 2 kg (4.4 lb) since her last visit. The blood pressure was 160/90 mm Hg, the heart rate was 79/min, the respiratory rate was 14/min, and the temperature was 37.0℃ (98.6℉). The physical examination shows leg and perineal edema. The neurologic examination is significant for symmetric upper and lower extremity hyperreflexia and ankle clonus. Which of the following laboratory findings would be most common in this patient?
rationale:
The patient's presentation is consistent with eclampsia, which is characterized by the new onset of seizures in a woman with preeclampsia. Preeclampsia is defined as new-onset hypertension and proteinuria after 20 weeks of gestation. Given the patient's symptoms of headache, lethargy, hypertension, and edema, along with the presence of proteinuria, the most common laboratory finding in this patient would be proteinuria. This is a hallmark feature of preeclampsia and eclampsia.

Hypokalemia, hypoglycemia, hypernatremia, and leukocytosis are not typically associated with preeclampsia and eclampsia.

sentence: A 3-year-old male is brought by his mother to the pediatrician's office. The mother and child are refugees from Somalia and arrived in the United States one week ago. They were recently placed in temporary housing. The mother reports that the child has been chronically tired and subdued since before their arrival in the United States. The child was born at 38 weeks gestation with the help of a local midwife. The child’s temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 105/60 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination reveals a listless child with a rotund abdomen and positive fluid wave. Notable lower extremity edema is present. This patient's condition is most likely caused by a deficiency in which of the following?
rationale:
1. The child's symptoms of chronic tiredness, subdued behavior, and physical exam findings of a rotund abdomen, lower extremity edema, and positive fluid wave are consistent with protein-energy malnutrition, specifically kwashiorkor.
2. Kwashiorkor is caused by a relative deficiency in protein intake, leading to edema and abdominal distension.
3. The child's symptoms are not consistent with deficiencies in vitamin D, iron, vitamin B12, or calcium.
4. Therefore, the most likely cause of the child's condition is a relative protein intake deficiency.

sentence: A 42-year-old woman presents to her obstetrician for a prenatal care appointment at 10 weeks gestation. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 127/68 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, you notice a gravid uterus 10 cm above the pubic symphysis. The patient's external genitalia appear within normal limits. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
rationale:
The next best step in management for this patient is cell-free DNA testing. This test can be used to screen for fetal aneuploidy, including trisomy 21 (Down syndrome), trisomy 18, and trisomy 13. It is a non-invasive test that can be performed as early as 10 weeks gestation and has a high sensitivity and specificity for detecting these chromosomal abnormalities.

Transvaginal ultrasound, maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein screening, and amniocentesis are not indicated at this time, as the patient is only 10 weeks gestation and does not have any specific indications for these tests. 

A nonstress test is used to monitor fetal well-being and is typically performed later in pregnancy, usually after 28 weeks gestation. It is not indicated at this early stage of pregnancy.

sentence: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of abdominal distention, fatigue, and night sweats over the past 4 months. He also has a 2-month history of post-prandial fullness and recurrent nonbilious vomiting. He appears pale. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and shifting dullness; there is mild tenderness to palpation. Examination of the skin shows multiple nonblanching maculae. A CT scan of the abdomen shows mesenteric and retroperitoneal lymph node enlargement and nodular thickening of the omentum. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen from an enlarged mesenteric lymph node is shown. Immunohistochemical staining of the Ki-67 nuclear antigen shows that the proliferation index of the specimen is > 99%. The structure indicated by the arrows is most likely which of the following?
rationale: The photomicrograph and immunohistochemical staining findings are consistent with a diagnosis of Burkitt lymphoma, a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma. The structure indicated by the arrows is most likely a macrophage, as it is a key component of the tumor microenvironment in Burkitt lymphoma. Macrophages play a role in promoting tumor growth and survival in the tumor microenvironment. The other cell types listed (neutrophil, B lymphocyte, T lymphocyte, plasma cell) are not typically associated with the tumor microenvironment in Burkitt lymphoma.

sentence:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother after falling from the jungle gym and developing severe left knee pain and swelling. On presentation, he is found to be in pain with a hot, swollen, erythematous left knee. His past medical history is significant for abnormal coagulation lab tests before an appendectomy, but his mother cannot recall the exact details. Coagulation tests are conducted with the following results:

Bleeding time: 3 minutes
Prothrombin time: 11 seconds
Partial thromboplastin time: 53 seconds
Bradykinin formation: decreased

Which of the following factors is most likely defective in this patient?
rationale:
1. The prolonged partial thromboplastin time (PTT) suggests a deficiency in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.
2. Factor XII is part of the intrinsic pathway and is involved in the activation of the coagulation cascade.
3. The decreased bradykinin formation is also consistent with a deficiency in factor XII, as factor XII is involved in the formation of bradykinin.
4. Therefore, the most likely factor that is defective in this patient is factor XII.

sentence: A 52-year-old man with Crohn disease comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of dysuria and urinary urgency. He had been treated for urinary tract infections twice in the past 6 months. He is currently taking infliximab. Cystoscopy shows pearl-like plaques on the bladder wall. Biopsy of these lesions shows a focal layer of stratified squamous epithelium with hyperkeratosis. If the patient's bladder finding is caused by a vitamin deficiency, which of the following features is also most likely to be seen?
rationale:
The bladder finding described in the scenario is consistent with bladder involvement in Crohn disease, known as enterovesical fistula. This can lead to the passage of bacteria from the intestines into the bladder, causing recurrent urinary tract infections. The patient is also taking infliximab, which is a tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor used to treat Crohn disease.

The bladder finding and the history of Crohn disease suggest that the patient may have a vitamin deficiency, specifically vitamin A deficiency. The pearl-like plaques on the bladder wall and the biopsy findings of stratified squamous epithelium with hyperkeratosis are consistent with squamous metaplasia, which can occur in the bladder due to chronic irritation and inflammation.

If the bladder finding is caused by a vitamin deficiency, the patient is also likely to have other features of vitamin A deficiency, such as night blindness. Vitamin A deficiency can lead to impaired dark adaptation and night blindness due to its role in the visual cycle and maintenance of the corneal and conjunctival epithelium.

Peripheral neuropathy, anemia, and osteoporosis are not typically associated with vitamin A deficiency. Therefore, the most likely feature to be seen in this patient if the bladder finding is caused by a vitamin deficiency is night blindness.

sentence: A 26-year-old gravida 2 para 1 at 24 weeks gestation is admitted to the labor and delivery suite with mild abdominal cramps, uterine contractions, and a watery vaginal discharge. She has a history of preterm birth. The vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 125/80 mm Hg; heart rate 100/min; respiratory rate 13/min; and temperature 36.6℃ (97.9℉). The pelvic examination reveals cervical softening and shortening. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a cervical length of 12 mm, which is consistent with preterm labor. A tocolytic and a single dose of betamethasone are administered. Betamethasone stimulates which fetal cells?
rationale: Betamethasone is a corticosteroid that is given to pregnant women at risk of preterm delivery to help mature the fetal lungs. It stimulates the production of surfactant by the fetal type II pneumocytes in the lungs. Surfactant is important for reducing surface tension in the alveoli and preventing collapse, which is crucial for the baby's ability to breathe after birth. Therefore, the correct answer is type II pneumocytes.

sentence: A 55-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after collapsing at the grocery store and losing consciousness for 1 minute following a sudden onset of palpitations. He has no chest pain or dizziness. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and is currently being treated as an outpatient for pneumonia. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and azithromycin. He has no sign of injury, and he appears well. During the examination, he loses consciousness again. Telemetry shows polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with cyclic alteration of the QRS axis, which spontaneously resolves after 30 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's syncope?
rationale:
1. The patient's history of sudden onset of palpitations followed by loss of consciousness and telemetry showing polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with cyclic alteration of the QRS axis is consistent with Torsades de Pointes, which is often associated with a prolonged QT interval.
2. The patient's medications, including azithromycin, can prolong the QT interval, increasing the risk of Torsades de Pointes.
3. Hypoglycemia, drug interaction, atrial fibrillation, and pulmonary embolism are less likely to cause the specific pattern of ventricular tachycardia described in the scenario.
4. Therefore, the most likely underlying cause of this patient's syncope is a prolonged QT interval.

sentence: A 56-year-old patient is being treated with oral amoxicillin for community-acquired pneumonia. The plasma clearance of the drug is calculated as 15.0 L/h. Oral bioavailability of the drug is 75%. Sensitivity analysis of a sputum culture shows a minimal inhibitory concentration of 1 μg/mL for the causative pathogen. The target plasma concentration is 2 mg/L. If the drug is administered twice per day, which of the following dosages should be administered at each dosing interval to maintain a steady state?
rationale:
1. The target plasma concentration is 2 mg/L, and the oral bioavailability is 75%. This means that the effective target concentration is 2 mg/L / 0.75 = 2.67 mg/L.
2. The plasma clearance is 15.0 L/h, and the dosing interval is twice per day, so the total daily clearance is 15.0 L/h * 24 h/day = 360 L/day.
3. To maintain a steady state, the total daily dose needed to achieve the target concentration is 360 L/day * 2.67 mg/L = 960 mg/day.
4. Since the drug is administered twice per day, the dosage at each dosing interval should be 960 mg/day / 2 = 480 mg.
5. Therefore, the correct dosage to be administered at each dosing interval to maintain a steady state is 480 mg.

sentence:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician’s office by his parents after they noticed blood in his urine. The child has been complaining of difficulty in passing urine and has lower abdominal pain. He seems more bloated than usual. On some occasions, he starts crying while passing urine, primarily because of a burning sensation. A urinalysis is performed, and the results are as follows:
Urine pH 6.2
Urine specific gravity 1.010
Glucose Negative
Ketones Negative
RBCs 1-2/hpf
WBCs 0-1/hpf
Casts 2-3/hpf
The pediatrician believes the boy has a bladder infection with a double-stranded DNA virus. Which of the following conditions is also commonly associated with this viral infection?
rationale:
The symptoms described, along with the presence of blood in the urine and the urinalysis findings, are consistent with a urinary tract infection. The presence of a double-stranded DNA virus suggests that the viral infection is likely caused by adenovirus.

Adenovirus infections are commonly associated with gastroenteritis, which is characterized by symptoms such as diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Therefore, the most likely condition commonly associated with this viral infection is gastroenteritis.

sentence: A 46-year-old woman presents with difficulty initiating sleep, as well as frequent nighttime awakenings. She reports making multiple mistakes at her office job, has an inability to concentrate, and feels sleepy throughout the day. She is worried that her sleeping troubles will cause her to get fired. Which of the following would best treat this patient’s insomnia pharmacologically?
rationale:
1. Triazolam is a short-acting benzodiazepine that is commonly used to treat insomnia, especially difficulty with sleep initiation.
2. Melatonin is a hormone that can help regulate sleep-wake cycles, but it may not be strong enough to treat this patient's severe insomnia.
3. Trazodone is an antidepressant that is sometimes used off-label to treat insomnia, but it may not be the best choice for this patient's symptoms.
4. Zolpidem is a non-benzodiazepine sedative-hypnotic that is also used to treat insomnia, but it may not be the best choice for this patient's symptoms.
5. Diphenhydramine is an antihistamine that can cause drowsiness and is sometimes used as a sleep aid, but it may not be the best choice for this patient's symptoms.
6. Therefore, the best pharmacological treatment for this patient's insomnia would be triazolam.

distractors: Facial rash and blood in the urine
Profound leukopenia increasing the risk for severe infection
Weight gain and change in hair color
sentence: A 5-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician for evaluation of difficulties noted at school. Her kindergarten teacher voiced her concern that the child ‘spaces out’ often and thinks she may have ADHD. The parents deny any history of head trauma or infection. Her blood pressure is 106/74 mm Hg, the heart rate is 69/min, and the respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical exam demonstrates a happy child who has reached developmental milestones. Laboratory results are within normal limits. EEG demonstrates a 3-Hz spike and wave pattern (see image). The decision is made to start the child on medical therapy. What should be advised to the parents as a potential side effect of the first-line medication?
rationale:
1. The 3-Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG is consistent with a diagnosis of absence seizures, which is a type of epilepsy.
2. The first-line medication for absence seizures in children is ethosuximide.
3. Ethosuximide is known to have potential side effects, including gastrointestinal (GI) upset, such as nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
4. Therefore, the parents should be advised that GI upset is a potential side effect of the first-line medication for their child's condition.

sentence: A 75-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue over the past month. He reports that he cannot climb more than one flight of stairs without experiencing shortness of breath and dizziness. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He does not drink alcohol. His medications include enalapril, atorvastatin, and low-dose aspirin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows weak peripheral pulses. Cardiac examination is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
rationale:
1. The weak peripheral pulses and the findings on cardiac examination are consistent with aortic valve stenosis.
2. Aortic valve stenosis can cause symptoms of progressive shortness of breath and fatigue, especially with exertion.
3. The patient's history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking are risk factors for developing aortic valve stenosis.
4. Atrial fibrillation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and mitral valve regurgitation are less likely based on the patient's presentation and physical examination findings.
5. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis for this patient is aortic valve stenosis.

distractors: Increased binding of calcium to calmodulin
Decreased production of cyclic guanosine monophosphate
sentence: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination 1 week after a temporal artery biopsy was performed to evaluate headache and blurry vision. He has a 12-year history of hypertension treated with lisinopril. Results of the testing show decreased concentrations of arginine in vascular endothelial cells. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?
rationale:
1. Decreased concentrations of arginine in vascular endothelial cells can be caused by increased production of nitric oxide. Nitric oxide is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase, so increased production of nitric oxide can lead to decreased concentrations of arginine.
2. Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that can actually increase arginine levels by inhibiting its breakdown, so it is not the most likely explanation for decreased arginine concentrations.
3. Atherosclerosis is a condition characterized by the buildup of plaque in the arteries, but it is not directly related to decreased concentrations of arginine in vascular endothelial cells.
4. Temporal arteritis is an inflammatory condition of the blood vessels, but it is not directly related to decreased concentrations of arginine in vascular endothelial cells.
5. Therefore, the most likely explanation for the finding of decreased concentrations of arginine in vascular endothelial cells is increased production of nitric oxide.

answer: “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of nonmaleficence.”
distractors: “I can not help you due to the ethical principle of autonomy.”
“I can not help you due to the ethical principle of justice.”
“I can not help you due to the ethical principle of beneficence.”
sentence: While traveling abroad a physician is asked to attend a meeting regarding healthcare in the region. The rate of chlamydial infection is exceptionally high in the area, and the local government is wanting to test a new treatment for these infections. To test the new therapy, the physician is asked to oversee the operations of testing this new treatment. When asking what this would entail, the officials tell the physician that they plan to infect the local prison population with chlamydia and then test the new treatment on these individuals. Which of the following is the best response from the physician?
generated_distractors: I think this is a great idea and I am willing to help with the testing.
I will need to consult with my colleagues before making a decision.
I am not comfortable with this, but I will consider it if the potential benefits outweigh the risks.
I will need to review the research protocol before making a decision.
rationale: The best response from the physician is to assert the ethical principle of nonmaleficence, which emphasizes the obligation to do no harm. Infecting individuals with a disease for the purpose of testing a new treatment would clearly violate this principle. Therefore, the physician should firmly decline to participate in such testing.

sentence: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 7-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath. She has a history of asthma and has frequent exacerbations despite receiving maximal medical therapy. Physical examination shows scattered expiratory wheezing. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 9,800/mm3 (13% eosinophils) and elevated serum concentration of immunoglobulin E. An x-ray of the chest shows thickened bronchial walls and perihilar opacities. Sputum culture shows scattered septate hyphae that branch at 45 degrees. Which of the following is most likely to be increased in this patient?
rationale:
1. The patient's history of asthma, elevated serum concentration of immunoglobulin E, and sputum culture showing septate hyphae that branch at 45 degrees are consistent with allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
2. In ABPA, there is an increased production of IL-4, which is a key cytokine involved in the pathogenesis of the condition.
3. IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine and would not be expected to be increased in this condition.
4. IFN-gamma is involved in the immune response to intracellular pathogens and would not be expected to be increased in ABPA.
5. TNF-alpha is a pro-inflammatory cytokine, but it is not specifically associated with ABPA.
6. IL-17 is associated with inflammatory conditions such as psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis, but it is not specifically associated with ABPA.
7. Therefore, the most likely cytokine to be increased in this patient is IL-4.

sentence: A 29-year-old G1P0 female presents at 22 weeks gestation for her first prenatal care appointment. Physical exam demonstrates a uterine size greater than expected for her gestational age and taut, shiny skin with scattered striae on her abdomen. Ultrasound examination of the fetus reveals 2.5 L of amniotic fluid (normal 1.5-2.0 L) with an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 34 (normal AFI 20-25). Which of the following fetal abnormalities or dysfunctions could have contributed to these abnormal ultrasound findings?
rationale:
1. The increased amniotic fluid volume (polyhydramnios) and taut, shiny skin with scattered striae on the mother's abdomen are consistent with polyhydramnios, which can be caused by fetal abnormalities or dysfunctions.
2. Duodenal atresia is a condition in which there is a blockage in the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), leading to an accumulation of amniotic fluid in the uterus. This can result in polyhydramnios and is consistent with the ultrasound findings in this case.
3. Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is not typically associated with polyhydramnios.
4. Renal agenesis, fetal anencephaly, and fetal hydrops can all lead to abnormal amniotic fluid volume, but they are not specifically associated with the taut, shiny skin and scattered striae seen on the mother's abdomen.
5. Therefore, the most likely fetal abnormality or dysfunction contributing to these abnormal ultrasound findings is duodenal atresia.

sentence: A 68-year-old woman presents to the emergency room with chest pain. She reports sudden severe and crushing substernal chest pain that started 1 hour ago. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes mellitus, obesity, and a prior myocardial infarction requiring a coronary artery bypass graft 2 years ago. She takes aspirin, metoprolol, lisinopril, spironolactone, atorvastatin, and insulin. She is retired and lives a sedentary lifestyle at home. Her temperature is 98.8°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 109/68 mmHg, pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 24/min. Before being able to start the physical examination, the patient loses consciousness. Her pulse is palpable but weak. Her blood pressure is now 88/50 mmHg and pulse is 130/min. Her skin is pale, cold, and clammy. An electrocardiogram demonstrates ST elevations in leads I, aVL, V3, V4, V5, and V6. A medication that primarily stimulates which of the following receptors would be most appropriate to improve the hemodynamic status of this patient?
rationale:
1. The patient is presenting with symptoms of cardiogenic shock, which is characterized by decreased cardiac output and tissue hypoperfusion.
2. A medication that primarily stimulates the beta-1 adrenergic receptor would be most appropriate to improve the hemodynamic status of this patient. Stimulation of the beta-1 adrenergic receptor increases heart rate, contractility, and conduction velocity, which can help improve cardiac output and blood pressure in a patient with cardiogenic shock.
3. Stimulation of the alpha-1 adrenergic receptor would primarily cause vasoconstriction, which may increase afterload and worsen the patient's condition.
4. Dopamine receptor stimulation is not the primary target for improving hemodynamic status in this patient.
5. Serotonin and muscarinic acetylcholine receptor stimulation are not appropriate for improving hemodynamic status in this patient.
6. Therefore, the most appropriate medication to improve the hemodynamic status of this patient would primarily stimulate the beta-1 adrenergic receptor.

sentence: A 4-year-old child is rushed to the emergency department after developing sudden abdominal pain followed by nausea, vomiting, and dark, almost black-colored stool. Prior to the onset of symptoms, he was seen playing with his mother’s purse containing a bottle of vitamin supplements, which she takes for chronic microcytic anemia. Which of the following medications is the treatment for this patient's intoxication?
rationale:
1. The child likely ingested iron supplements from his mother's purse, leading to iron poisoning.
2. Deferoxamine is the specific antidote for iron poisoning, as it chelates iron and enhances its excretion from the body.
3. N-acetylcysteine is used as an antidote for acetaminophen poisoning.
4. Activated charcoal is used to absorb toxins in the gastrointestinal tract, but it is not specific for iron poisoning.
5. Flumazenil is used as an antidote for benzodiazepine overdose.
6. Naloxone is used as an antidote for opioid overdose.
7. Therefore, the treatment for this patient's intoxication with iron supplements is deferoxamine.

sentence: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, breast tenderness, increased urinary frequency, and intermittent nausea for 2 weeks. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She has a history of a seizure disorder treated with carbamazepine. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. The child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
rationale:
1. The patient is pregnant and has been taking carbamazepine, which is known to increase the risk of neural tube defects such as meningocele in the developing fetus.
2. Meningocele is a type of neural tube defect in which the protective covering of the spinal cord (meninges) protrudes through an opening in the spine.
3. Carbamazepine is known to increase the risk of neural tube defects when taken during pregnancy.
4. Therefore, the child is at greatest risk of developing a meningocele as a complication of the mother's carbamazepine use during pregnancy.

sentence:
Three patients present to the pediatrician for routine well-child visits. The first child’s mother reports that he seems to be breastfeeding well and voids at least eight times per day. His stools are a yellow color, and he does not seem to be straining. In the office, he can lift his head and chest when in the prone position, and he can track an object with his eyes to the midline. His hands remain fisted 50% of the time.

The second child’s parents report that she is doing well at home and seems to enjoy playing with her older brother. In the office, she can roll from supine to prone and can transfer her rattle from hand to hand. She cannot yet say any words.

The third child’s father reports that he is starting to explore the world around him. He has begun taking independent steps at home. In the office, he seems to recognize the name of several objects, but he cannot follow the direction to “grab the ball.” All three children are assessed as developmentally normal.

Which of the following represents these patient's respective ages?
rationale:
1. The first child is able to lift his head and chest when in the prone position, and can track an object with his eyes to the midline. He also has fisted hands 50% of the time. These are typical developmental milestones for a 2-month-old infant.

2. The second child can roll from supine to prone and can transfer her rattle from hand to hand. She cannot yet say any words. These are typical developmental milestones for a 6-month-old infant.

3. The third child has begun taking independent steps and seems to recognize the name of several objects. These are typical developmental milestones for a 12-month-old infant.

Therefore, the respective ages of these patients are 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months.

sentence: A 75-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with 30 minutes of slurred speech and arm weakness. On the drive over to the hospital, her symptoms have resolved completely. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, atrial fibrillation, diabetes, morbid obesity, gout, and vascular claudication. Her temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 184/111 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam reveals cranial nerves II-XII as grossly intact with normal strength and sensation in the patient's upper and lower extremities. The patient's memory is intact and her speech seems normal and fluent. Her gait is stable with no ataxia. An initial head CT demonstrates diffuse atrophy which is consistent with previous head CT scans. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
rationale:
The patient's presentation is concerning for a transient ischemic attack (TIA) given the sudden onset of neurological symptoms that resolved completely within 24 hours. Given her history of hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and diabetes, she is at high risk for cerebrovascular disease.

The best next step in management is to perform a CT angiogram to evaluate the blood vessels in the brain and neck. This will help identify any potential stenosis or occlusion that may have caused the TIA.

Administering tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) is not indicated in this case as the patient's symptoms have already resolved completely.

Starting anticoagulation therapy may be considered if a thrombus or embolus is identified on the CT angiogram, but it is not the best initial step in management.

Performing carotid endarterectomy may be considered if significant carotid artery stenosis is identified on the CT angiogram, but it is not the best initial step in management.

Beginning antiplatelet therapy may be considered after the CT angiogram if atherosclerosis or small vessel disease is identified, but it is not the best initial step in management.

sentence: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with weakness. He states that it started yesterday and has been progressively worsening. Initially, he noticed blurry vision and some trouble speaking and swallowing but thought he was just coming down with a cold. He then noticed weakness of his facial muscles and shortness of breath. The patient works as a farmer and harvests and cans his own foods. He has had diarrhea recently and a cough prior to these symptoms of weakness. His temperature is 97.9°F (36.6°C), blood pressure is 144/94 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam is notable for a man who seems unable to smile with dysarthric speech. He takes shallow and weak breaths on pulmonary exam. The patient demonstrates 3/5 strength with diminished reflexes in his upper extremities. The patient is subsequently intubated. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
rationale:
1. The patient's symptoms, including weakness, blurry vision, trouble speaking and swallowing, facial muscle weakness, and shortness of breath, are consistent with botulism, which is caused by the toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum bacteria.
2. The best treatment for botulism is antitoxin, which can help neutralize the toxin and prevent further progression of symptoms.
3. Antibiotics, antivirals, and corticosteroids are not effective treatments for botulism.
4. IV fluids may be used to support the patient's respiratory function and hydration, but the best treatment to address the underlying cause of the symptoms is antitoxin.

sentence: A 79-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of difficulty starting urination and a vague sensation of fullness in the pelvis. Pelvic speculum examination in the lithotomy position shows a pink structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall when the patient is asked to cough. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
rationale:
1. The pink structure at the vaginal introitus that protrudes from the anterior vaginal wall when the patient coughs is consistent with a cystocele, which is a protrusion of the bladder into the vagina.
2. A rectocele is a protrusion of the rectum into the vagina, which would not present with difficulty starting urination.
3. Uterine prolapse would involve the descent or protrusion of the uterus into the vagina, but it would not cause difficulty starting urination.
4. Vaginal cancer may present with pelvic symptoms, but it would not typically cause a visible protrusion at the vaginal introitus.
5. A urinary tract infection may cause urinary symptoms, but it would not cause a visible protrusion at the vaginal introitus.
6. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is a cystocele.

sentence: A 30-year-old woman presents to the physician because of ongoing diarrhea for the past 1 month. She reports that diarrhea has been intermittently present for the past month. The stool is often loose and associated with blood and lower abdominal pain. She denies any recent travel history, and she works at a nursing home as a caretaker. She is not currently on any medications. Clinical examination shows mild tenderness in the suprapubic region, and there is no organomegaly. Findings on colonoscopy include patchy erythema and ulceration in the cecum, ascending, descending, and sigmoid colon. Mucosal biopsy shows colonic crypts with lymphocytic and neutrophilic infiltrates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
rationale:
1. The patient's symptoms of ongoing diarrhea, intermittent presence of loose stool with blood, and lower abdominal pain are consistent with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
2. The patchy erythema and ulceration seen on colonoscopy, along with the mucosal biopsy showing colonic crypts with lymphocytic and neutrophilic infiltrates, are characteristic of Crohn's disease.
3. Ulcerative colitis typically presents with continuous colonic involvement and does not typically involve the small intestine, which is a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease.
4. Infectious colitis would typically have a more acute onset and would be more likely in a patient with recent travel history or exposure to infectious agents.
5. Irritable bowel syndrome does not typically present with bloody diarrhea or mucosal inflammation seen on colonoscopy and biopsy.
6. Ischemic colitis would typically present with a history of vascular disease or risk factors for vascular compromise, which are not mentioned in the scenario.
7. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and findings is Crohn's disease.

sentence: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being stabbed 12 times in various parts of his body. Paramedics report extensive blood loss at the scene where he was found. Due to his Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3, an endotracheal airway and large-bore access are secured prior to arrival. He is aggressively resuscitated with a massive transfusion protocol as the operating room is prepared for an exploratory laparotomy. An arterial line and central access are obtained. His temperature is 95°F (35°C), blood pressure is 50/40 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min, and respirations are controlled at 20/min on lung-protective volume control. After a 6:6:1 ratio of red blood cells, plasma, and platelets and the use of continuous phenylephrine infusion, the patient's vital signs remain the same. The surgical team reports no active blood loss. A stat ScvO2 results as 39% with a SaO2 of 100% on 100% oxygen. His extremities remain cold despite having the ambient room temperature increased to 80°F (26.7°C). What is the most likely cause of his presentation?
rationale:
1. The patient's presentation with extensive blood loss, hypotension, and cold extremities despite resuscitation suggests a form of shock.
2. The lack of improvement in vital signs despite aggressive resuscitation and the use of vasopressors suggests a mechanical obstruction to cardiac filling, such as cardiac tamponade.
3. Hypothermia could contribute to the patient's presentation, but it is not the primary cause of his hemodynamic instability.
4. Tension pneumothorax and acute respiratory distress syndrome are less likely given the patient's presentation and the lack of improvement with resuscitation efforts.
5. Disseminated intravascular coagulation could be a complication of the patient's extensive injuries and blood loss, but it is not the primary cause of his presentation.
6. Therefore, the most likely cause of his presentation is cardiac tamponade.

sentence: A 71-year-old woman presents to her physician accompanied by her son. She has no complaints, but her son states that the patient has impaired memory and poor orientation in space. She is ambulatory and is capable of self-care, but she tends to forget newly introduced information. Also, she got lost on the way from the home to the local market several times for the past 6 months, and her family is now afraid to let her go anywhere on her own. She does not have any concomitant chronic conditions nor did she have major cardiovascular events or head trauma. It is known that her father had dementia. The vital signs include: blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, heart rate is 62/min, respiratory rate is 11/min, and the temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F). The respiratory, cardiologic, and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. The neurological examination shows equal, round pupils with a normal reaction to light. The eye movements are normal with no nystagmus and normal oculocephalic reflex. There is no facial droop, the facial sensation is preserved, and there is no tongue deviation noted. There is no motor or sensory deficits on the upper and lower extremities. The patient scores 18 on the Montreal Cognitive Assessment. Which of the following medications is indicated in the patient?
rationale:
1. The patient's symptoms and family history are consistent with Alzheimer's disease, a type of dementia.
2. The Montreal Cognitive Assessment score of 18 indicates mild cognitive impairment, which is often a precursor to Alzheimer's disease.
3. Donepezil is a medication commonly used to treat the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease, including memory loss and confusion.
4. Aspirin, atorvastatin, metoprolol, and warfarin are not indicated for the treatment of Alzheimer's disease.

sentence: A 16-year-old teenager presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe pain in his right knee. He describes the pain as the worst pain he has ever felt. He denies any recent trauma or injury to the knee. The joint appears red and swollen and is hot to the touch. He denies any lower extremity numbness. There is no family history of joint or connective tissue disorders. The teenager is otherwise healthy. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg, respirations are 17/min, pulse is 104/min, and temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). On palpation of the affected joint, there is evidence of tenderness and capsular swelling; the joint is red and warm. Laboratory studies show increased serum CRP and procalcitonin levels. Which of the following will most likely found with analysis of his synovial fluid?
rationale:
The sudden onset of severe pain, redness, and swelling in the knee joint, along with the patient's symptoms of fever and elevated inflammatory markers, are consistent with a diagnosis of septic arthritis.

Analysis of the synovial fluid in septic arthritis typically shows a very high white blood cell count (WBC), with a predominance of polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) indicating an acute inflammatory response. The viscosity of the synovial fluid is usually low due to the presence of inflammatory cells and exudative fluid.

Therefore, the most likely findings with analysis of his synovial fluid would be WBC/mm3 53,000; % PMN > 75%; Viscosity low.

sentence:
An otherwise healthy 49-year-old woman has a routine full blood count complete prior her elective cholecystectomy. The lab test results are as follows:
Laboratory test
Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)
85 μm3
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)
47%
Reticulocyte count
3.4 %
White blood cell count
9700/mm3
